title: Neurosyphilis
scope: ** Evaluation and management of neurosyphilis including early neurosyphilis (meningeal, meningovascular), late neurosyphilis (general paresis, tabes dorsalis), and ocular/otic syphilis. Includes diagnosis, treatment with IV penicillin G, management of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction, penicillin desensitization for allergic patients, and post-treatment monitoring with serial CSF analysis. Excludes primary/secondary syphilis without CNS involvement, congenital syphilis, and HIV-specific antiretroviral management.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Non-treponemal screening test; quantitative titer used for treatment response monitoring; sensitivity ~70-80% in late syphilis (prozone effect possible)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Reactive with titer (document titer for follow-up comparison)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Alternative non-treponemal screening; quantitative titer; VDRL is the only validated non-treponemal test for CSF
Treponemal confirmatory test; remains positive for life after infection; high sensitivity and specificity
Treponemal confirmatory test; alternative to FTA-ABS; high specificity
Many labs now use reverse screening algorithm (treponemal test first); automated, high throughput
High co-infection rate (syphilis-HIV co-infection in 25-70% in some populations); HIV affects neurosyphilis presentation, treatment response, and monitoring schedule
Essential/Core Labs.target: Document result; if positive, obtain CD4 and viral load

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; infection markers; lymphocytosis may be present
Renal function for penicillin dosing; hepatic function; electrolytes
Elevated in active syphilis; non-specific inflammatory marker

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: CD4 count and HIV viral load (CPT 86360)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: If HIV positive; CD4 <350 increases risk of neurosyphilis; affects monitoring frequency

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Hepatitis B surface antigen, surface antibody, core antibody (CPT 87340)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Co-infection screening (shared risk factors); hepatitis may complicate treatment
STI co-infection screening; shared risk factors
Subacute combined degeneration in differential (posterior column dysfunction like tabes dorsalis)
Thyroid dysfunction in differential of cognitive decline
SLE meningitis/cerebritis in differential; biological false-positive RPR seen in SLE

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Limited availability; lower sensitivity than serology; may be useful in early infection before antibody response
Syphilis can cause biological false-positive; meningovascular syphilis with stroke differential includes antiphospholipid syndrome
General paresis may mimic autoimmune encephalitis (psychiatric symptoms, cognitive decline)
Whipple disease in differential (dementia, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia)

Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal or mildly elevated (10-20 cm H2O); elevated in acute meningitis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: CSF pleocytosis is the hallmark of active neurosyphilis; lymphocytic predominant; most sensitive CSF marker
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC >5 cells/uL (lymphocyte predominant); typically 10-400 cells/uL; elevated WBC is the most sensitive indicator of active CNS infection

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: May be mildly decreased; helps distinguish from other causes of meningitis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal or mildly low (>60% serum glucose ratio); markedly low glucose suggests bacterial or TB meningitis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: GOLD STANDARD for neurosyphilis diagnosis; highly SPECIFIC (99%) but sensitivity only 30-70%. A REACTIVE CSF VDRL confirms neurosyphilis. A NON-REACTIVE CSF VDRL does NOT exclude neurosyphilis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Reactive = diagnostic of neurosyphilis. Non-reactive does NOT rule out neurosyphilis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: More SENSITIVE than CSF VDRL (>95%) but LESS SPECIFIC (false positives from blood contamination). A NEGATIVE CSF FTA-ABS essentially rules out neurosyphilis. Used mainly to EXCLUDE the diagnosis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Non-reactive = neurosyphilis unlikely. Reactive = possible neurosyphilis (but not confirmatory due to lower specificity)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: NOT validated for CSF; some labs offer it but CSF VDRL is the standard non-treponemal test for CSF
Lumbar Puncture.target: CSF VDRL preferred; CSF RPR has uncertain performance characteristics

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Exclude bacterial meningitis if acute presentation
Rapid multiplex PCR to exclude bacterial/viral meningitis if acute presentation
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative (no bacterial or viral pathogen identified)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Intrathecal antibody production; elevated in neurosyphilis; also elevated in MS (differential)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Often positive (intrathecal IgG synthesis); not specific to syphilis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: TB meningitis in differential (chronic lymphocytic meningitis)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h; STAT if acute stroke symptoms or altered consciousness
Essential/First-line.target: Meningovascular: cerebral infarction (especially MCA territory in young patient), meningeal enhancement, gummatous lesions. General paresis: frontotemporal atrophy, mesial temporal T2 hyperintensity. Tabes dorsalis: spinal cord atrophy. May be NORMAL in early/asymptomatic neurosyphilis

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate in ED if acute presentation (stroke, altered consciousness, seizure)
Essential/First-line.target: Infarction (meningovascular), hydrocephalus, calcified gumma; may be normal
Baseline; syphilitic aortitis (conduction abnormalities); QTc for concurrent medications

Extended.timing: If myelopathy symptoms (tabes dorsalis, syphilitic myelitis)
Extended.target: Spinal cord atrophy (tabes dorsalis: posterior columns), meningeal enhancement, myelitis signal change

Extended.timing: If meningovascular syphilis with stroke suspected
Extended.target: Arteritis; vessel wall enhancement; stenosis (medium and large vessels); aneurysm

Extended.timing: If MRA not available and stroke suspected
If cardiovascular syphilis suspected (aortitis); concurrent evaluation
Extended.target: Aortic regurgitation; ascending aortic aneurysm; aortitis
Ascending aortic calcification (eggshell pattern); aortic dilatation

Rare/Specialized.timing: If meningovascular syphilis with negative standard MRA
Rare/Specialized.target: Concentric vessel wall enhancement (vasculitis pattern); distinguishes from atherosclerotic disease

Rare/Specialized.timing: Atypical cognitive decline; general paresis with unclear diagnosis
If seizures or altered mental status
Rare/Specialized.target: Focal slowing; generalized slowing (general paresis); epileptiform discharges

Rare/Specialized.timing: Peripheral neuropathy evaluation; tabes dorsalis differential
Rare/Specialized.target: Sensory neuropathy pattern; dorsal root ganglionopathy

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line treatment for ALL forms of neurosyphilis (meningeal, meningovascular, general paresis, tabes dorsalis, ocular syphilis, otic syphilis)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Penicillin G (aqueous crystalline) (CPT 96365) 3-4 million units q4h IV

dosing.instructions: 18-24 million units/day IV, given as 3-4 million units IV q4h continuously for 10-14 days. Infuse each dose over 30-60 min. Alternative: continuous IV infusion 18-24 million units/day. Duration: minimum 10-14 days
dosing.orderSentence: Penicillin G (aqueous crystalline) (CPT 96365) 3-4 million units q4h IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Penicillin anaphylaxis (perform desensitization -- see below); dose adjust for severe renal impairment (CrCl <10: 2-3 million units q4h)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Renal function (BUN, Cr) daily; serum potassium (high-dose penicillin contains potassium); CBC; monitor for Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction in first 24h; monitor for seizures at very high doses

Acute/Emergent.indication: Maintain hydration during IV penicillin therapy; prevent volume depletion

dosing.instructions: 75-125 mL/h IV maintenance; bolus 500-1000 mL if dehydrated

Acute/Emergent.indication: Prophylaxis and treatment of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (fever, rigors, headache, myalgia occurring 2-8h after first penicillin dose; occurs in up to 50% of neurosyphilis patients)

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h for first 24-48h of treatment; premedicate before first penicillin dose

Acute/Emergent.indication: Prevention of severe Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction in patients at high risk (high RPR titer, HIV co-infection, ocular/otic syphilis with risk of permanent vision/hearing loss, meningovascular syphilis with stroke risk)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Methylprednisolone 1 g IV daily x3-5 days

dosing.instructions: 60-125 mg IV 30 min before first penicillin dose to attenuate Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction

Acute/Emergent.indication: Used ONLY with procaine penicillin G IM regimen (alternative to IV penicillin when IV access impossible); blocks renal excretion of penicillin to maintain treponemicidal CSF levels

doseOptions.orderSentence: Probenecid (with IM penicillin alternative) 500 mg QID PO

dosing.instructions: 500 mg PO QID for 10-14 days (must be given with each IM penicillin dose); ensure adequate hydration
dosing.orderSentence: Probenecid (with IM penicillin alternative) 500 mg QID PO

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Uric acid nephrolithiasis; blood dyscrasias; sulfonamide allergy
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Uric acid; renal function; ensure compliance (QID dosing)

Acute/Emergent.item: Procaine penicillin G IM (alternative ONLY if IV not feasible)
Acute/Emergent.indication: Alternative to IV penicillin G ONLY when IV access is impossible. MUST be combined with probenecid. CDC considers this acceptable but less preferred than IV

doseOptions.orderSentence: Procaine penicillin G IM (alternative ONLY if IV not feasible) 2.4 million units daily IM

dosing.instructions: 2.4 million units IM daily for 10-14 days PLUS probenecid 500 mg PO QID. This regimen REQUIRES strict compliance with probenecid; any missed doses compromise CSF levels
dosing.orderSentence: Procaine penicillin G IM (alternative ONLY if IV not feasible) 2.4 million units daily IM

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Injection sites; compliance with probenecid; clinical response

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (lightning pains of tabes dorsalis; lancinating pain)

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q1-3d to 300-900 mg TID; max 3600 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (tabes dorsalis; alternative to gabapentin)

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg BID; may increase to 150-300 mg BID q1wk; max 600 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); angioedema history
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; weight gain; edema; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Lancinating/lightning pain of tabes dorsalis (particularly effective for paroxysmal neuropathic pain)

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg BID; titrate by 200 mg/day q1wk; target 400-800 mg/day; max 1200 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: AV block; history of bone marrow suppression; concurrent MAOIs; HLA-B*1502 positive (Asian descent -- screen before starting)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: CBC with differential q2wk x 2 months then q3 months; LFTs; sodium (SIADH); drug level (target 4-12 ug/mL)

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily x 1 wk; increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: LFTs; blood pressure; serotonin syndrome symptoms

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Seizures (neurosyphilis-related seizures; meningovascular with cortical involvement)

dosing.instructions: 1000-1500 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; max 3000 mg/day
0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg); may repeat x1 in 5 min

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Depression (common with general paresis and chronic neurosyphilis)

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg daily; increase by 50 mg q2-4wk; max 200 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Psychotic symptoms (general paresis with psychosis, paranoid delusions, grandiosity)

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg BID; titrate slowly to 50-100 mg BID; target 150-300 mg/day for psychosis

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Metabolic panel q3 months; fasting glucose; lipids; QTc; tardive dyskinesia monitoring

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Acute agitation with psychosis (general paresis with severe agitation)

dosing.instructions: 2-5 mg IV/IM q4-6h PRN; max 20 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: QT prolongation; Parkinson disease; dementia (black box)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Gastroparesis (visceral autonomic neuropathy in tabes dorsalis)

dosing.instructions: 10 mg PO 30 min before meals and at bedtime; max 40 mg/day; limit to 12 weeks

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Parkinson disease; tardive dyskinesia; bowel obstruction

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Bladder dysfunction (neurogenic bladder in tabes dorsalis; urgency/incontinence)

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg BID; may increase to 5 mg TID; max 15 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Urinary retention; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma; GI obstruction
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Post-void residual; anticholinergic effects (cognition in elderly)

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Alternative for neurosyphilis when penicillin desensitization is not feasible; CDC-recommended alternative. Evidence supports adequate CSF penetration and treponemicidal activity

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ceftriaxone IV (alternative to penicillin G) 2 g daily IV

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV daily for 10-14 days. Some experts recommend 14 days. Limited clinical trial data but supported by observational studies and CDC guidelines
dosing.orderSentence: Ceftriaxone IV (alternative to penicillin G) 2 g daily IV

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Cephalosporin anaphylaxis; severe penicillin allergy with cephalosporin cross-reactivity (low risk, ~1-2%)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Renal function; CBC; LFTs; biliary sludge with prolonged use

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Penicillin allergy with no acceptable alternative; allows safe IV penicillin G administration. Desensitization takes 4-6 hours and must be done in monitored setting (ICU or equivalent)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Penicillin desensitization protocol (for penicillin-allergic patients) See Appendix A PO then IV

dosing.instructions: Oral desensitization protocol over 4-6h (see Appendix A); begin IV penicillin G immediately after desensitization complete; patient must remain on continuous penicillin (no gaps >8h or desensitization is lost)
dosing.orderSentence: Penicillin desensitization protocol (for penicillin-allergic patients) See Appendix A PO then IV

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Anaphylaxis to penicillin (proceed with extreme caution in ICU); unstable cardiac/respiratory status
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Continuous cardiac monitoring; SpO2; BP q15min during protocol; epinephrine at bedside; IV access x2; crash cart available

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Third-line alternative ONLY when both IV penicillin and ceftriaxone are contraindicated; limited evidence for neurosyphilis; better studied for early syphilis

dosing.instructions: 200 mg PO BID for 28 days. Some experts recommend 30 days. LOWER confidence in CNS penetration; use only if no other option. Close CSF monitoring mandatory

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: LFTs; sun protection counseling; GI tolerance; photosensitivity

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Adjunctive anti-inflammatory therapy for ocular syphilis (uveitis, optic neuritis, retinal vasculitis) or otic syphilis to prevent permanent vision/hearing loss; used in addition to IV penicillin, not as standalone

doseOptions.orderSentence: Corticosteroids (adjunctive for ocular/otic syphilis) 1 mg/kg daily PO

dosing.instructions: Prednisone 1 mg/kg/day PO (max 60 mg) with IV penicillin; taper over 2-4 weeks based on ophthalmology/ENT guidance; or IV methylprednisolone 250 mg q6h x 3 days then oral taper for severe cases
dosing.orderSentence: Corticosteroids (adjunctive for ocular/otic syphilis) 1 mg/kg daily PO

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Uncontrolled diabetes; active GI bleed; psychosis (relative)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Glucose; BP; GI prophylaxis; ophtho/ENT follow-up

Referrals & Consults.item: Infectious disease consultation for treatment optimization, duration guidance, penicillin desensitization planning, and HIV co-management
Neurology consultation for diagnosis confirmation, CSF interpretation, differentiation of neurosyphilis subtypes, and management of neurologic complications
Ophthalmology STAT evaluation for ALL patients with ocular symptoms (vision loss, floaters, photophobia) as ocular syphilis can cause permanent blindness without prompt treatment
Audiology evaluation for ALL patients with hearing loss or tinnitus (otic syphilis) for baseline audiometry and monitoring
ENT consultation for otic syphilis evaluation and management of sensorineural hearing loss
Psychiatry consultation for behavioral/psychiatric symptoms in general paresis (psychosis, personality change, cognitive decline, depression)
Allergy/Immunology consultation for penicillin desensitization if patient reports penicillin allergy
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive testing in suspected general paresis (dementia evaluation, treatment response monitoring)
Physical therapy for gait training, balance rehabilitation, and fall prevention in tabes dorsalis (sensory ataxia, proprioceptive loss)
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment and adaptive strategies given proprioceptive and fine motor deficits
Social work for STI partner notification coordination, housing stability, substance use resources, and discharge planning
Public health department notification (syphilis is a reportable disease in all US states)
Sexual health/STI clinic referral for partner notification, ongoing STI screening, and prevention counseling

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED if: new vision loss, worsening headache, new weakness, seizure, confusion, hearing loss, or high fever after starting treatment (Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction may worsen in first 24h)
Complete the FULL course of IV penicillin (10-14 days); do NOT stop treatment early even if symptoms improve, as incomplete treatment leads to relapse and progressive CNS damage

Expect possible fever, chills, headache, and muscle aches within 2-12 hours of first penicillin dose (Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction); this is a normal inflammatory response and NOT an allergic reaction; notify nursing staff but do NOT stop antibiotics
Abstain from sexual contact until treatment is complete and RPR titers decline to confirm cure; use condoms consistently after treatment
All sexual partners from the past 90 days (primary), 6 months (secondary), or 1 year (latent) must be notified and tested for syphilis
Follow-up blood tests (RPR titers) required at 3, 6, 12, and 24 months after treatment to confirm cure; failure of titers to decline by 4-fold at 6-12 months may indicate treatment failure
Follow-up lumbar puncture required at 6 months (and possibly 3, 12, and 24 months) after treatment to confirm CSF normalization
Report any new neurologic symptoms (vision changes, hearing changes, numbness, balance problems, cognitive changes) between follow-up visits as they may indicate treatment failure or reinfection
If HIV positive: ensure adherence to antiretroviral therapy as HIV co-infection increases risk of treatment failure and neurosyphilis relapse
Driving restrictions if cognitive impairment, seizures, or significant visual deficit until cleared by neurology

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Safer sex practices: consistent condom use reduces but does not eliminate syphilis transmission risk; regular STI screening for sexually active individuals
Alcohol cessation as alcohol worsens cognitive impairment and neuropathy, and complicates medication adherence and follow-up
HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) discussion for patients at ongoing risk who are HIV-negative
Fall prevention measures including assistive devices, home safety evaluation, and nightlight use for patients with sensory ataxia (tabes dorsalis), as proprioceptive loss worsens in darkness
Cognitive rehabilitation strategies including memory aids, structured routines, and supervised medication management for patients with general paresis
Regular exercise appropriate to functional level for cardiovascular health and prevention of deconditioning
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk (especially important in meningovascular syphilis with stroke risk)

differential.features: Progressive cognitive decline in HIV; may coexist with neurosyphilis; no CSF pleocytosis unless opportunistic infection
differential.tests: HIV viral load (CSF and serum); CD4 count; syphilis serologies negative; MRI: diffuse atrophy

differential.features: Subacute/chronic meningitis; basilar predominance; cranial neuropathies; CSF: lymphocytic, very low glucose, very high protein
differential.tests: AFB culture; TB PCR (GeneXpert); ADA; chest X-ray (miliary pattern); PPD/IGRA

differential.features: HIV/immunocompromised; chronic headache; elevated opening pressure; minimal pleocytosis
differential.tests: CSF cryptococcal antigen; India ink; fungal culture; serum CrAg

differential.features: Multifocal strokes in young patient; headache; cognitive decline; CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: Brain biopsy (gold standard); vessel wall MRI; CTA/MRA; ESR/CRP; ANA; ANCA; syphilis serologies to exclude

differential.features: Relapsing-remitting neurologic deficits; optic neuritis; myelopathy; white matter lesions
differential.tests: MRI (periventricular/juxtacortical lesions; Dawson fingers); CSF oligoclonal bands; syphilis screen (should be done in all MS workups)

differential.features: Psychiatric symptoms; seizures; movement disorders; subacute onset
differential.tests: Autoimmune encephalitis antibody panel (serum + CSF); MRI; EEG

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies (especially CN VII); chronic meningitis; granulomatous inflammation
differential.tests: Chest CT (hilar adenopathy); serum/CSF ACE; biopsy; CSF lymphocytic; syphilis serologies negative

differential.features: Progressive cognitive decline in immunocompromised; periventricular enhancing lesion
differential.tests: MRI with contrast; CSF cytology; EBV PCR (CSF); stereotactic biopsy

differential.features: Triad: gait apraxia, urinary incontinence, dementia; ventriculomegaly out of proportion to atrophy
differential.tests: Large volume LP (improvement after 30-40 mL removal); MRI (ventriculomegaly, DESH); gait assessment pre/post LP

differential.features: Posterior column dysfunction (like tabes dorsalis); peripheral neuropathy; megaloblastic anemia
differential.tests: Serum B12; methylmalonic acid; homocysteine; MRI spine (dorsal column signal)

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies (CN VII); radiculopathy; meningitis; endemic area exposure; erythema migrans history
differential.tests: Lyme serologies (ELISA + Western blot); CSF Lyme antibody index; CSF pleocytosis

differential.features: Oculomasticatory myorhythmia (pathognomonic); dementia; GI symptoms; arthritis
differential.tests: Whipple PCR (CSF/tissue); small bowel biopsy; PAS-positive macrophages

differential.features: Oral/genital ulcers; uveitis; CNS involvement; young adults; Mediterranean/Asian descent
differential.tests: Clinical criteria (recurrent ulcers); pathergy test; HLA-B51; CSF pleocytosis

differential.features: Persistent headache, cranial neuropathies, CSF pleocytosis >4 weeks
differential.tests: Full chronic meningitis workup: syphilis, TB, fungal, Lyme, sarcoid, malignancy

evidence.recommendation: IV penicillin G 18-24 million units/day x 10-14 days for neurosyphilis
evidence.source: [CDC STI Treatment Guidelines 2021](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34292926/); [Workowski et al. MMWR 2021](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34292926/)

evidence.recommendation: CSF VDRL is the standard diagnostic test for neurosyphilis (highly specific but insensitive)
CSF FTA-ABS has high negative predictive value (negative result essentially excludes neurosyphilis)
CSF pleocytosis (WBC >5) is the most sensitive marker of active neurosyphilis
Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily x 10-14 days as alternative to penicillin
evidence.source: [Marra et al. CID 2000](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11749352/); CDC STI Guidelines 2021

evidence.recommendation: Serial CSF monitoring at 6-month intervals post-treatment
HIV co-infection increases risk of neurosyphilis and treatment failure
LP recommended for all HIV-positive patients with syphilis (especially CD4 <350 or RPR >=1:32)
evidence.source: [Ghanem et al. STD 2009](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20180366/); CDC STI Guidelines 2021

evidence.recommendation: Ocular syphilis requires neurosyphilis treatment (IV penicillin) regardless of CSF findings
evidence.source: [Oliver et al. STD 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28702511/); CDC Clinical Advisory 2015

evidence.recommendation: Otic syphilis requires neurosyphilis treatment (IV penicillin) regardless of CSF findings
Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction occurs in up to 50% of neurosyphilis patients
evidence.source: Expert consensus; [Belum et al. Am J Med 2013](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23996476/)

evidence.recommendation: Penicillin desensitization is safe and effective for penicillin-allergic patients requiring treatment
Four-fold decline in serum RPR by 6-12 months defines adequate treatment response
CSF WBC should normalize within 6 months of successful treatment
Retreatment indicated if CSF WBC has not declined at 6 months
evidence.source: CDC STI Guidelines 2021; [Marra et al. CID 2004](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15796090/)

evidence.recommendation: Doxycycline 200 mg BID x 28 days as third-line alternative (limited evidence)
evidence.source: Expert consensus; limited data for CNS penetration

evidence.recommendation: All patients with syphilis should be tested for HIV
evidence.source: CDC STI Treatment Guidelines 2021; WHO Guidelines

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (mental status, cranial nerves, motor, sensory, gait)
monitoring.action: If declining: reassess treatment; repeat imaging; repeat LP

monitoring.frequency: q2h for first 24h of treatment, then q4h
monitoring.action: Acetaminophen; IV fluids; if severe: corticosteroids; do NOT stop penicillin

monitoring.frequency: Baseline, then at 3, 6, 12, and 24 months post-treatment
monitoring.action: If no 4-fold decline by 6-12 months: consider treatment failure; repeat LP; retreat

monitoring.item: CSF analysis (cell count, protein, VDRL) -- follow-up LP
monitoring.frequency: At 6 months post-treatment; repeat q6 months until normal; some experts also check at 3, 12, 24 months
monitoring.action: If CSF WBC not declining at 6 months: retreat with IV penicillin 10-14 days; if HIV+, check at 3 months

monitoring.frequency: Daily during IV penicillin (high-dose penicillin contains 1.7 mEq K+ per million units)
monitoring.action: If hyperkalemic: reduce potassium intake; cardiac monitoring; if hypokalemic: supplement

monitoring.frequency: Daily during IV penicillin; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: Dose adjust penicillin if renal impairment develops
Urgent ophthalmology re-evaluation if worsening; reassess corticosteroid dose

monitoring.frequency: Baseline, then at 1, 3, 6, 12 months if otic syphilis

monitoring.item: HIV viral load and CD4 (if co-infected)
monitoring.frequency: At syphilis diagnosis, then per HIV monitoring schedule
monitoring.action: If unsuppressed HIV: higher risk of neurosyphilis treatment failure; optimize ART

monitoring.frequency: Clinical observation inpatient; EEG if seizures
monitoring.action: Adjust AED; if status epilepticus: follow SE protocol
If hypertensive crisis during JH reaction: treat symptomatically

disposition.disposition: Discharge home (with OPAT -- outpatient parenteral antibiotic therapy)
disposition.criteria: Neurologically stable; no active seizures; mild symptoms; reliable outpatient IV access (PICC line); home infusion services arranged; reliable patient with follow-up arranged; no significant comorbidities requiring monitoring

Confirmed or highly suspected neurosyphilis requiring IV penicillin initiation; need for Jarisch-Herxheimer monitoring; moderate neurologic deficits; seizure monitoring; ocular or otic syphilis requiring urgent subspecialty evaluation

Severe meningovascular syphilis with acute stroke; status epilepticus; acute vision loss requiring emergent management; penicillin desensitization protocol (requires continuous monitoring); severe Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction with hemodynamic instability; altered consciousness (GCS <13)
Need for penicillin desensitization not available at current facility; need for neuro-ophthalmology not available; need for neurosurgery if hydrocephalus or mass lesion

Asymptomatic neurosyphilis with mild CSF abnormalities; stable patient who can receive IV penicillin via OPAT or complete procaine penicillin IM + probenecid regimen; established diagnosis with completed inpatient treatment transitioning to monitoring
